thread.title: Armour: Cubs just getting started - this year, and for many to come
thread.title_full: Armour: Cubs just getting started - this year, and for many to come

title: Armour: Cubs just getting started - this year, and for many to come
text:
Kyle Schwarber powered another long home run, and the young Cubs overpowered the veteran Cardinals. (Photo: Jerry Lai, USA TODAY Sports)
1 CONNECT 11 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE CHICAGO - Everybody in baseball ought to feel the sting of the beatdown the Chicago Cubs put on the St. Louis Cardinals.
If not, they’ll experience it for themselves soon enough.
It wasn’t just that the Cubs overwhelmed the Cardinals in taking this National League Division Series 3-1, it was that they just kept coming. In Tuesday’s 6-4 victory, Javier Baez, who spent the season in Iowa, hit a three-run homer. Jorge Soler made the defensive play of the series, throwing out Tony Cruz on a one-hopper to home to save what would have been a go-ahead run for St. Louis.
USA TODAY
Cubs knock out Cardinals, advance to NLCS with Wrigley party
Anthony Rizzo and Kyle Schwarber homered, with the ball Schwarber hit still streaking somewhere over Lake Michigan.
They’re like baseball’s version of the White Walkers in Game of Thrones . Except scarier because they’re only getting started.
Rizzo is the grizzled veteran of the bunch at 26. Soler is 23. Schwarber and Baez are 22. There’s also Kris Bryant, the likely Rookie of the Year at 23. And Addison Russell, who is all of 21.
They’ve played all of five postseason games, and already they’ve combined for nine home runs and 17 RBIs.
This series wasn’t only a changing of the guard in the NL Central, where the Cardinals have finished first or second in each of the last seven seasons. It’s a sneak peek at what baseball is going to look like for the next decade.
Hope is usually in rare supply for Cubs fans, a century’s worth of disappointment and futility engraining doubt and realism into their DNA. But they have dared to dream this year, buoyed by the promise of these youngsters.
It’s fitting, then, that they clinched their biggest win this decade on the four-year anniversary of Theo Epstein’s arrival in Chicago. It’s Epstein and his general manager, Jed Hoyer, who turned the franchise upside down so they could build a new foundation.
The first few years were painful, no doubt. The Cubs lost – and lost often – while Epstein and Hoyer restocked the farm system. As Bryant, Schwarber and the rest started coming through Iowa, there were hints of how good these new Cubs could be.
USA TODAY
Mets' Wilmer Flores at shortstop: 'I feel very comfortable'
The initial thinking was that 2016 was going to be Chicago’s year – it’s always next year on the North Side, after all. But when they were able to lure rookie whisperer Joe Maddon to Chicago, the plan accelerated.
Now there doesn’t seem to be any stopping them. This year, or for many to come.
GALLERY: Cubs take out Cards in NLDS
